#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make Flaxseed Oil
#Text=Flaxseed oil offers a variety of healthy benefits .
#Text=It is rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids , which are thought to help with the inflammation associated with rheumatoid arthritis and other inflammatory diseases .
#Text=You can purchase the oil at many health food stores , but you can also make the oil at home .
#Text=With a hot or cold oil press , you can produce pure oil from flaxseeds .
#Text=If you do n't want to invest in a press , you can make whole flaxseed oil , which requires boiling the seeds in water to release its oils .
#Text=Because it 's prepared with water , though , it is diluted so it is n't a true oil .
#Text=Ingredients
#Text=Pressed
#Text=Flaxseed Oil
#Text=1 pound ( 454 g ) flaxseeds
#Text=Whole Flaxseed Oil
#Text=1 to 2 tablespoons ( 10 to 20 g ) whole flaxseeds
#Text=2 cups ( 473 ml ) water
#Text=Steps
#Text=Creating Pressed Flaxseed Oil
#Text=Set up the press .
#Text=To make flaxseed oil , you can use a hot oil press or a cold oil press .
#Text=Hot presses are usually freestanding machines that you must turn on and allow to heat up before you can use them .
#Text=Cold oil presses are usually attachments that connect to a juicer .
#Text=Turn on or attach your press according to the manufacturer ’s instructions .
#Text=A hot press usually produces more oil because the heat helps soften the seeds to make it easier to extract the oil .
#Text=It also makes the process go more quickly .
#Text=You should usually allow a hot press to heat up for at least 10 minutes .
#Text=A cold press usually requires more time to produce oil .
#Text=However , it often leads to a better-tasting oil with more nutrients .
#Text=Add the seeds to the machine ’s funnel .
#Text=You can use any amount of flaxseeds based on how much oil you need .
#Text=However , if you ’re making oil for the first time , it ’s best to start with a small amount to get used to the process .
#Text=A pound ( 454 g ) is usually a good amount to start with .
#Text=Place the seeds in the hot press ’s hopper or the cold press ’s feed compartment .
#Text=Crank or turn on the machine to extract the oil .
#Text=Some hot presses only require pressing a button to start the extraction .
#Text=However , others require hand cranking to produce the oil .
#Text=With a cold press attachment , you ’ll need to simply turn on the juicer to start the extraction process .
#Text=Consult the manufacturer ’s guide for the press or press attachment to ensure that you know how to use it .
#Text=Make sure that you have a container or collection cup set up beneath the extractor ’s spout so you do n’t lose any oil .
#Text=Process the seeds according to the type of extractor you 're using .
#Text=The amount of time necessary to process all of the seeds depends on the amount and the type of extractor you ’re using .
#Text=For 1 pound ( 454 g ) of seeds in a hot press , it will usually take 5 to 10 minutes .
#Text=With a cold press , it may take up to a half hour .
#Text=Cap the container of oil .
#Text=When you ’re finished extracting the oil , turn off your extractor .
#Text=If you collected the oil in a collection cup , use a funnel to transfer it to an airtight container .
#Text=Close the container , making sure that it 's tightly sealed .
#Text=Let the oil sit for a few days .
#Text=There may be sediment in the oil that you 'll want to separate out .
#Text=If you allow it to sit for 2 to 3 days , the sediment will settle at the bottom so it 's easier to siphon off the oil .
#Text=If your extractor is equipped with a sieve or filter , most or all of the sediment will already be removed so this step may be unnecessary .
#Text=You may still want to let the oil sit , though , to be sure that all of the sediment is removed .
#Text=Filter off the oil and discard the sediment .
#Text=After a few days , open the oil and pour it through a sieve into a second airtight container .
#Text=Close the container , and store it in a cool , dry location .
#Text=It should stay fresh for up to 2 years .
#Text=If you do n’t have a sieve , you can usually just pour off the oil from the top of the container because all of the sediment will be at the bottom .
#Text=Preparing Whole Flaxseed Oil
#Text=Boil the water .
#Text=Add 2 cups ( 473 ml ) of water to a small saucepan , and place it on the stove .
#Text=Heat it on high until it comes to a boil , which should take about 5 minutes .
#Text=Add the seeds and lower the heat .
#Text=Once the oil is boiling , mix 1 to 2 tablespoons ( 10 to 20 g ) of whole flax seeds into the water .
#Text=Reduce the stove ’s heat to medium-low , and let the seeds cook .
#Text=Continue to cook the seeds for about 8 minutes until the mixture thickens .
#Text=With the pan uncovered and the heat on medium-low , let the seeds boil in the water .
#Text=The water should become thick and glossy , and you may also notice streaks that look somewhat like egg whites when the oil is ready .
#Text=Allow the mixture to cool .
#Text=When the seeds are finished cooking , turn off the heat and remove the pan from the stove .
#Text=Let it cool on the countertop for 20 to 30 minutes .
#Text=There 's no need to strain the seeds from the mixture after it 's cooled .
#Text=They will actually break down during the cooking process , so they soften and release their oils .
#Text=However , if you prefer to remove the seeds , you can run the oil through a sieve after it 's cooled .
#Text=Transfer it to a jar and store in the refrigerator for up to 10 days .
#Text=When the oil is cool enough to handle , pour it into an airtight container .
#Text=Close it securely , and place it in the refrigerator for storage .
#Text=It should stay fresh for up to a week and half .
#Text=Things
#Text=You ’ll Need
#Text=Pressed Flaxseed Oil
#Text=Hot or cold oil
#Text=press
#Text=Collection
#Text=cup
#Text=Sieve
#Text=Airtight jar or bottle
#Text=Whole Flaxseed Oil
#Text=Small saucepan
#Text=Airtight jar or bottle
